text:
Fractions: Equivalence & Addition

Fractions represent parts of a whole. Two fractions are equivalent if you multiply/divide numerator and denominator by the same nonzero number. To add/subtract, use a common denominator (often the least common denominator, LCD).

metadata.title: Fractions: Equivalence & Addition
metadata.retrieval_queries: equivalent fractions | LCD | add subtract fractions
metadata.citations: OpenStax Prealgebra: Fractions - OpenStax
metadata.text:
Fractions: Equivalence & Addition

Fractions represent parts of a whole. Two fractions are equivalent if you multiply/divide numerator and denominator by the same nonzero number. To add/subtract, use a common denominator (often the least common denominator, LCD).

text:
Learning objectives for Fractions: Equivalence & Addition:
Generate equivalent fractions
Find common denominators
Add/subtract fractions and mixed numbers

metadata.title: Fractions: Equivalence & Addition
metadata.retrieval_queries: equivalent fractions | LCD | add subtract fractions
metadata.citations: OpenStax Prealgebra: Fractions - OpenStax
metadata.text:
Learning objectives for Fractions: Equivalence & Addition:
Generate equivalent fractions
Find common denominators
Add/subtract fractions and mixed numbers

text:
Misconception 1: Add numerators and denominators straight across.
Refutation: Denominator must match.
Explanation: You combine like-size parts only.

Misconception 2: LCD must be denominator product.
Refutation: Use the least common multiple.
Explanation: Smaller LCD simplifies work.

metadata.title: Fractions: Equivalence & Addition
metadata.retrieval_queries: equivalent fractions | LCD | add subtract fractions
metadata.citations: OpenStax Prealgebra: Fractions - OpenStax
metadata.text:
Misconception 1: Add numerators and denominators straight across.
Refutation: Denominator must match.
Explanation: You combine like-size parts only.

Misconception 2: LCD must be denominator product.
Refutation: Use the least common multiple.
Explanation: Smaller LCD simplifies work.

text:
Question 1: Equivalent to 3/4?
Answer: 6/8, 9/12, …
Rationale: Multiply both by same number.

Question 2: Add 1/3 + 1/6.
Answer: 1/2
Rationale: LCD=6 → 2/6 + 1/6 = 3/6=1/2.

Question 3: Subtract 5/8 − 1/4.
Answer: 3/8
Rationale: 1/4=2/8 → 5/8−2/8=3/8.

metadata.title: Fractions: Equivalence & Addition
metadata.retrieval_queries: equivalent fractions | LCD | add subtract fractions
metadata.citations: OpenStax Prealgebra: Fractions - OpenStax
metadata.text:
Question 1: Equivalent to 3/4?
Answer: 6/8, 9/12, …
Rationale: Multiply both by same number.

Question 2: Add 1/3 + 1/6.
Answer: 1/2
Rationale: LCD=6 → 2/6 + 1/6 = 3/6=1/2.

Question 3: Subtract 5/8 − 1/4.
Answer: 3/8
Rationale: 1/4=2/8 → 5/8−2/8=3/8.

text:
Worked Example for Fractions: Equivalence & Addition:
Step: LCD of 3 and 4 is 12. - Why: Least common denominator.
Step: Convert: 2/3=8/12; 3/4=9/12. - Why: Equivalent fractions.
Step: Add: 17/12 = 1 5/12. - Why: Combine like parts; convert improper to mixed.

Step: Add: 17/12 = 1 5/12. - Why: Combine like parts; convert improper to mixed.

text:
Order of Operations & Negatives

Evaluate expressions using parentheses → exponents → multiplication/division (left to right) → addition/subtraction (left to right). 
Treat subtraction as adding a negative; be careful with −a^2 vs (−a)^2.

metadata.title: Order of Operations & Negatives
metadata.retrieval_queries: PEMDAS left-to-right | negatives vs subtraction | parentheses effect
metadata.citations: OpenStax Prealgebra: Order of Operations - OpenStax
metadata.text:
Order of Operations & Negatives

Evaluate expressions using parentheses → exponents → multiplication/division (left to right) → addition/subtraction (left to right). 
Treat subtraction as adding a negative; be careful with −a^2 vs (−a)^2.

text:
Learning objectives for Order of Operations & Negatives:
Apply PEMDAS with attention to grouping
Handle negatives and subtraction correctly
Evaluate simple expressions reliably

metadata.title: Order of Operations & Negatives
metadata.retrieval_queries: PEMDAS left-to-right | negatives vs subtraction | parentheses effect
metadata.citations: OpenStax Prealgebra: Order of Operations - OpenStax
metadata.text:
Learning objectives for Order of Operations & Negatives:
Apply PEMDAS with attention to grouping
Handle negatives and subtraction correctly
Evaluate simple expressions reliably

text:
Misconception 1: Multiplication always before division.
Refutation: They share priority; go left to right.
Explanation: Same for addition/subtraction.

Misconception 2: −a^2 means (−a)^2.
Refutation: Exponent binds before unary minus.
Explanation: −a^2 = −(a^2). (−a)^2 squares the negative.

metadata.title: Order of Operations & Negatives
metadata.retrieval_queries: PEMDAS left-to-right | negatives vs subtraction | parentheses effect
metadata.citations: OpenStax Prealgebra: Order of Operations - OpenStax
metadata.text:
Misconception 1: Multiplication always before division.
Refutation: They share priority; go left to right.
Explanation: Same for addition/subtraction.

Misconception 2: −a^2 means (−a)^2.
Refutation: Exponent binds before unary minus.
Explanation: −a^2 = −(a^2). (−a)^2 squares the negative.

text:
Question 1: Compute −3^2.
Answer: −9
Rationale: Square first, then apply negative.

Question 2: Compute (−3)^2.
Answer: 9
Rationale: Parentheses change the base.

Question 3: Evaluate 8−3·2.
Answer: 2
Rationale: 3·2=6; 8−6=2.

metadata.title: Order of Operations & Negatives
metadata.retrieval_queries: PEMDAS left-to-right | negatives vs subtraction | parentheses effect
metadata.citations: OpenStax Prealgebra: Order of Operations - OpenStax
metadata.text:
Question 1: Compute −3^2.
Answer: −9
Rationale: Square first, then apply negative.

Question 2: Compute (−3)^2.
Answer: 9
Rationale: Parentheses change the base.

Question 3: Evaluate 8−3·2.
Answer: 2
Rationale: 3·2=6; 8−6=2.

text:
Worked Example for Order of Operations & Negatives:
Step: Compute 2^3=8; 8−5=3. - Why: Inside parentheses first.
Step: Multiply: 3·(−2)=−6. - Why: Then multiplication.
Step: Subtract: 4−(−6)=10. - Why: Subtracting a negative adds.

metadata.title: Order of Operations & Negatives
metadata.retrieval_queries: PEMDAS left-to-right | negatives vs subtraction | parentheses effect
metadata.citations: OpenStax Prealgebra: Order of Operations - OpenStax
metadata.text:
Worked Example for Order of Operations & Negatives:
Step: Compute 2^3=8; 8−5=3. - Why: Inside parentheses first.
Step: Multiply: 3·(−2)=−6. - Why: Then multiplication.
Step: Subtract: 4−(−6)=10. - Why: Subtracting a negative adds.

text:
Solve One‑Variable Linear Equations

To solve, undo operations in reverse order on both sides to keep equality balanced. Combine like terms, isolate the variable, and check by substitution.

metadata.title: Solve One‑Variable Linear Equations
metadata.retrieval_queries: solve linear equation | inverse operations | check solution
metadata.citations: OpenStax Algebra: Linear Equations - OpenStax
metadata.text:
Solve One‑Variable Linear Equations

To solve, undo operations in reverse order on both sides to keep equality balanced. Combine like terms, isolate the variable, and check by substitution.

text:
Learning objectives for Solve One‑Variable Linear Equations:
Solve ax+b=c for x
Use inverse operations and maintain balance
Check solutions

metadata.title: Solve One‑Variable Linear Equations
metadata.retrieval_queries: solve linear equation | inverse operations | check solution
metadata.citations: OpenStax Algebra: Linear Equations - OpenStax
metadata.text:
Learning objectives for Solve One‑Variable Linear Equations:
Solve ax+b=c for x
Use inverse operations and maintain balance
Check solutions

text:
Misconception 1: Add to one side only.
Refutation: Apply operations to both sides.
Explanation: Preserves equality.

Misconception 2: Checking is optional.
Refutation: It confirms no arithmetic mistake.
Explanation: Plug back to verify.

metadata.title: Solve One‑Variable Linear Equations
metadata.retrieval_queries: solve linear equation | inverse operations | check solution
metadata.citations: OpenStax Algebra: Linear Equations - OpenStax
metadata.text:
Misconception 1: Add to one side only.
Refutation: Apply operations to both sides.
Explanation: Preserves equality.

Misconception 2: Checking is optional.
Refutation: It confirms no arithmetic mistake.
Explanation: Plug back to verify.

text:
Question 1: Solve 3x+5=20.
Answer: x=5
Rationale: 3x=15 → x=5.

Question 2: Solve 7−2x=1.
Answer: x=3
Rationale: −2x=−6 → x=3.

Question 3: What if variables cancel and 0=5?
Answer: No solution
Rationale: Inconsistent equation.

metadata.title: Solve One‑Variable Linear Equations
metadata.retrieval_queries: solve linear equation | inverse operations | check solution
metadata.citations: OpenStax Algebra: Linear Equations - OpenStax
metadata.text:
Question 1: Solve 3x+5=20.
Answer: x=5
Rationale: 3x=15 → x=5.

Question 2: Solve 7−2x=1.
Answer: x=3
Rationale: −2x=−6 → x=3.

Question 3: What if variables cancel and 0=5?
Answer: No solution
Rationale: Inconsistent equation.

text:
Worked Example for Solve One‑Variable Linear Equations:
Step: Distribute: 4x−8+3=19 → 4x−5=19. - Why: Remove parentheses.
Step: Add 5: 4x=24. - Why: Isolate variable term.
Step: Divide by 4: x=6; check. - Why: Complete isolation and verify.

Step: Add 5: 4x=24. - Why: Isolate variable term.
Step: Divide by 4: x=6; check. - Why: Complete isolation and verify.

text:
Proportions & Percentages

A proportion is an equality of two ratios (a/b = c/d). Cross‑multiply to solve (ad=bc). Percent means "per hundred"; convert by moving decimal two places. Percent change = (new−old)/old × 100%.

metadata.title: Proportions & Percentages
metadata.retrieval_queries: proportions solve | percent change problems | fraction decimal percent
metadata.citations: OpenStax Prealgebra: Ratios & Percents - OpenStax
metadata.text:
Proportions & Percentages

A proportion is an equality of two ratios (a/b = c/d). Cross‑multiply to solve (ad=bc). Percent means "per hundred"; convert by moving decimal two places. Percent change = (new−old)/old × 100%.

text:
Learning objectives for Proportions & Percentages:
Set up and solve proportions
Convert between fractions, decimals, percents
Solve percent increase/decrease problems

metadata.title: Proportions & Percentages
metadata.retrieval_queries: proportions solve | percent change problems | fraction decimal percent
metadata.citations: OpenStax Prealgebra: Ratios & Percents - OpenStax
metadata.text:
Learning objectives for Proportions & Percentages:
Set up and solve proportions
Convert between fractions, decimals, percents
Solve percent increase/decrease problems

text:
Misconception 1: Percent points equal percent change.
Refutation: Different quantities.
Explanation: From 10% to 12% is +2 percentage points = +20% change.

Misconception 2: Cross‑multiplying changes solutions.
Refutation: It’s algebraically equivalent.
Explanation: Both sides multiplied by bd.

metadata.title: Proportions & Percentages
metadata.retrieval_queries: proportions solve | percent change problems | fraction decimal percent
metadata.citations: OpenStax Prealgebra: Ratios & Percents - OpenStax
metadata.text:
Misconception 1: Percent points equal percent change.
Refutation: Different quantities.
Explanation: From 10% to 12% is +2 percentage points = +20% change.

Misconception 2: Cross‑multiplying changes solutions.
Refutation: It’s algebraically equivalent.
Explanation: Both sides multiplied by bd.

text:
Question 1: 0.35 as a percent?
Answer: 35%
Rationale: ×100.

Question 2: 30% of 80?
Answer: 24
Rationale: 0.30×80.

Question 3: Increase 50 by 20%.
Answer: 60
Rationale: 50×1.20.

metadata.title: Proportions & Percentages
metadata.retrieval_queries: proportions solve | percent change problems | fraction decimal percent

Question 1: 0.35 as a percent?
Answer: 35%
Rationale: ×100.

Question 2: 30% of 80?
Answer: 24
Rationale: 0.30×80.

Question 3: Increase 50 by 20%.
Answer: 60
Rationale: 50×1.20.

text:
Worked Example for Proportions & Percentages:
Step: Set ratio 3/2 = x/5. - Why: Keep units aligned.
Step: Cross‑multiply: 2x=15 → x=7.5. - Why: Solve proportion.
Step: Answer: 7.5 cups flour. - Why: Scale preserves ratio.

text:
Linear Functions: Slope–Intercept

A linear function has form y=mx+b where m is slope (rise/run) and b is y‑intercept. From point (x1,y1) and slope m, use point–slope: y−y1=m(x−x1).

metadata.title: Linear Functions: Slope–Intercept
metadata.retrieval_queries: slope intercept | point–slope form | x y intercepts
metadata.citations: OpenStax Algebra: Lines - OpenStax
metadata.text:
Linear Functions: Slope–Intercept

A linear function has form y=mx+b where m is slope (rise/run) and b is y‑intercept. From point (x1,y1) and slope m, use point–slope: y−y1=m(x−x1).

text:
Learning objectives for Linear Functions: Slope–Intercept:
Interpret slope and intercept
Write equation from two points or point–slope
Graph quickly from y=mx+b

metadata.title: Linear Functions: Slope–Intercept
metadata.retrieval_queries: slope intercept | point–slope form | x y intercepts
metadata.citations: OpenStax Algebra: Lines - OpenStax
metadata.text:
Learning objectives for Linear Functions: Slope–Intercept:
Interpret slope and intercept
Write equation from two points or point–slope
Graph quickly from y=mx+b

text:
Misconception 1: Slope is y/x.
Refutation: It’s change in y over change in x.
Explanation: Use differences: (y2−y1)/(x2−x1).

Misconception 2: Intercept is where the line touches the x‑axis.
Refutation: That’s x‑intercept; b is y‑intercept.
Explanation: Set x=0 to find y‑intercept.

metadata.title: Linear Functions: Slope–Intercept
metadata.retrieval_queries: slope intercept | point–slope form | x y intercepts
metadata.citations: OpenStax Algebra: Lines - OpenStax
metadata.text:
Misconception 1: Slope is y/x.
Refutation: It’s change in y over change in x.
Explanation: Use differences: (y2−y1)/(x2−x1).

Misconception 2: Intercept is where the line touches the x‑axis.
Refutation: That’s x‑intercept; b is y‑intercept.
Explanation: Set x=0 to find y‑intercept.

text:
Question 1: Slope through (1,2) and (3,6)?
Answer: 2
Rationale: (6−2)/(3−1)=4/2=2.

Question 2: Equation with m=−1, b=4?
Answer: y=−x+4
Rationale: Slope–intercept form.

Question 3: x‑intercept of y=2x−6?
Answer: 3
Rationale: Set y=0 → x=3.

metadata.title: Linear Functions: Slope–Intercept
metadata.retrieval_queries: slope intercept | point–slope form | x y intercepts
metadata.citations: OpenStax Algebra: Lines - OpenStax
metadata.text:
Question 1: Slope through (1,2) and (3,6)?
Answer: 2
Rationale: (6−2)/(3−1)=4/2=2.

Question 2: Equation with m=−1, b=4?
Answer: y=−x+4
Rationale: Slope–intercept form.

Question 3: x‑intercept of y=2x−6?
Answer: 3
Rationale: Set y=0 → x=3.

text:
Worked Example for Linear Functions: Slope–Intercept:
Step: Use point–slope: y−3=(1/2)(x−2). - Why: Relates slope to a point.
Step: Convert: y=(1/2)x+2. - Why: Simplify to slope–intercept.
Step: Check using (2,3). - Why: Verify point lies on line.

text:
Quadratic Basics: Factoring & Zeros

A quadratic is degree 2. If it factors as (x−r)(x−s), zeros are r and s since (x−r)(x−s)=0 ⇔ x=r or x=s. 
When a=1, look for numbers that multiply to c and add to b.

metadata.title: Quadratic Basics: Factoring & Zeros
metadata.retrieval_queries: factor quadratics | zero product property | parabola orientation
metadata.citations: OpenStax Algebra: Quadratics - OpenStax
metadata.text:
Quadratic Basics: Factoring & Zeros

A quadratic is degree 2. If it factors as (x−r)(x−s), zeros are r and s since (x−r)(x−s)=0 ⇔ x=r or x=s. 
When a=1, look for numbers that multiply to c and add to b.

text:
Learning objectives for Quadratic Basics: Factoring & Zeros:
Recognize standard form ax^2+bx+c
Factor simple quadratics (a=1)
Find zeros via factoring and the zero‑product property

metadata.title: Quadratic Basics: Factoring & Zeros
metadata.retrieval_queries: factor quadratics | zero product property | parabola orientation
metadata.citations: OpenStax Algebra: Quadratics - OpenStax
metadata.text:
Learning objectives for Quadratic Basics: Factoring & Zeros:
Recognize standard form ax^2+bx+c
Factor simple quadratics (a=1)
Find zeros via factoring and the zero‑product property

text:
Misconception 1: If a quadratic has no integer factors, it has no zeros.
Refutation: Zeros may be irrational/complex.
Explanation: Use quadratic formula if needed.

Misconception 2: Zero‑product works for sums.
Refutation: Only for products equal to zero.
Explanation: Sums cannot be split.

metadata.title: Quadratic Basics: Factoring & Zeros
metadata.retrieval_queries: factor quadratics | zero product property | parabola orientation
metadata.citations: OpenStax Algebra: Quadratics - OpenStax
metadata.text:
Misconception 1: If a quadratic has no integer factors, it has no zeros.
Refutation: Zeros may be irrational/complex.
Explanation: Use quadratic formula if needed.

Misconception 2: Zero‑product works for sums.
Refutation: Only for products equal to zero.
Explanation: Sums cannot be split.

text:
Question 1: Factor x^2+5x+6.
Answer: (x+2)(x+3)
Rationale: 2·3=6 and 2+3=5.

Question 2: Zeros of (x−4)(x+1)?
Answer: x=4, −1
Rationale: Set each factor to zero.

Question 3: Open upward or downward for y=−x^2+2x?
Answer: Downward
Rationale: a<0.

metadata.title: Quadratic Basics: Factoring & Zeros
metadata.retrieval_queries: factor quadratics | zero product property | parabola orientation
metadata.citations: OpenStax Algebra: Quadratics - OpenStax
metadata.text:
Question 1: Factor x^2+5x+6.
Answer: (x+2)(x+3)
Rationale: 2·3=6 and 2+3=5.

Question 2: Zeros of (x−4)(x+1)?
Answer: x=4, −1
Rationale: Set each factor to zero.

Question 3: Open upward or downward for y=−x^2+2x?
Answer: Downward
Rationale: a<0.

text:
Worked Example for Quadratic Basics: Factoring & Zeros:
Step: Find numbers multiplying to 12 and adding to −7: −3 and −4. - Why: Match b and c.
Step: Factor: (x−3)(x−4)=0. - Why: Rewrite as product.
Step: Set factors to zero: x=3 or x=4. - Why: Zero‑product property.

metadata.title: Quadratic Basics: Factoring & Zeros
metadata.retrieval_queries: factor quadratics | zero product property | parabola orientation
metadata.citations: OpenStax Algebra: Quadratics - OpenStax

Step: Find numbers multiplying to 12 and adding to −7: −3 and −4. - Why: Match b and c.
Step: Factor: (x−3)(x−4)=0. - Why: Rewrite as product.
Step: Set factors to zero: x=3 or x=4. - Why: Zero‑product property.

text:
Paragraph Structure & Cohesion

A strong paragraph opens with a topic sentence that advances the thesis, develops with evidence and analysis, and uses transitions and Given→New information flow so each sentence picks up something familiar before adding something new.

metadata.title: Paragraph Structure & Cohesion
metadata.retrieval_queries: topic sentence | transitions | given-new cohesion
metadata.citations: UNC Writing Center: Paragraphs - UNC Writing Center
metadata.text:
Paragraph Structure & Cohesion

A strong paragraph opens with a topic sentence that advances the thesis, develops with evidence and analysis, and uses transitions and Given→New information flow so each sentence picks up something familiar before adding something new.

text:
Learning objectives for Paragraph Structure & Cohesion:
Write clear topic sentences
Use logical order and transitions
Maintain sentence‑to‑sentence flow (Given→New)

metadata.title: Paragraph Structure & Cohesion
metadata.retrieval_queries: topic sentence | transitions | given-new cohesion
metadata.citations: UNC Writing Center: Paragraphs - UNC Writing Center
metadata.text:
Learning objectives for Paragraph Structure & Cohesion:
Write clear topic sentences
Use logical order and transitions
Maintain sentence‑to‑sentence flow (Given→New)

text:
Misconception 1: Any interesting sentence works as a topic sentence.
Refutation: It must advance the claim.
Explanation: Aligns with thesis.

Misconception 2: Transitions are optional.
Refutation: They guide readers.
Explanation: Signal relationships among ideas.

metadata.title: Paragraph Structure & Cohesion
metadata.retrieval_queries: topic sentence | transitions | given-new cohesion
metadata.citations: UNC Writing Center: Paragraphs - UNC Writing Center
metadata.text:
Misconception 1: Any interesting sentence works as a topic sentence.
Refutation: It must advance the claim.
Explanation: Aligns with thesis.

Misconception 2: Transitions are optional.
Refutation: They guide readers.
Explanation: Signal relationships among ideas.

text:
Question 1: Role of topic sentence?
Answer: State the paragraph’s claim
Rationale: Sets focus.

Question 2: Given→New pattern means…
Answer: Start with known info, then add new
Rationale: Smooth flow.

Question 3: Where to place evidence?
Answer: After the claim, integrated with analysis
Rationale: Support, not summary.

metadata.title: Paragraph Structure & Cohesion
metadata.retrieval_queries: topic sentence | transitions | given-new cohesion
metadata.citations: UNC Writing Center: Paragraphs - UNC Writing Center
metadata.text:
Question 1: Role of topic sentence?
Answer: State the paragraph’s claim
Rationale: Sets focus.

Question 2: Given→New pattern means…
Answer: Start with known info, then add new
Rationale: Smooth flow.

Question 3: Where to place evidence?
Answer: After the claim, integrated with analysis
Rationale: Support, not summary.

text:
Worked Example for Paragraph Structure & Cohesion:
Step: Identify repeated terms to carry forward. - Why: Build continuity.
Step: Reorder sentences to avoid abrupt topic shifts. - Why: Maintain flow.
Step: Insert transitions signaling cause/contrast/examples. - Why: Guide reader.

text:
Thesis & Topic Sentences

A thesis makes a specific claim you can support. Topic sentences are mini‑claims that advance the thesis. Avoid vague announcements ("This essay will discuss…").

metadata.title: Thesis & Topic Sentences
metadata.retrieval_queries: thesis vs topic | align reasons | claim-evidence structure
metadata.citations: Purdue OWL: Thesis Statements - Purdue OWL
metadata.text:
Thesis & Topic Sentences

A thesis makes a specific claim you can support. Topic sentences are mini‑claims that advance the thesis. Avoid vague announcements ("This essay will discuss…").

text:
Learning objectives for Thesis & Topic Sentences:
Draft a specific, arguable thesis
Align topic sentences to the thesis
Avoid announcement or fact-only theses

metadata.title: Thesis & Topic Sentences
metadata.retrieval_queries: thesis vs topic | align reasons | claim-evidence structure
metadata.citations: Purdue OWL: Thesis Statements - Purdue OWL
metadata.text:
Learning objectives for Thesis & Topic Sentences:
Draft a specific, arguable thesis
Align topic sentences to the thesis
Avoid announcement or fact-only theses

text:
Misconception 1: Thesis = topic.
Refutation: It must make a claim.
Explanation: Claim invites reasons and evidence.

Misconception 2: All topic sentences summarize evidence.
Refutation: They state a claim for that paragraph.
Explanation: Evidence comes after.

metadata.title: Thesis & Topic Sentences
metadata.retrieval_queries: thesis vs topic | align reasons | claim-evidence structure
metadata.citations: Purdue OWL: Thesis Statements - Purdue OWL
metadata.text:
Misconception 1: Thesis = topic.
Refutation: It must make a claim.
Explanation: Claim invites reasons and evidence.

Misconception 2: All topic sentences summarize evidence.
Refutation: They state a claim for that paragraph.
Explanation: Evidence comes after.

text:
Question 1: Which is a thesis: "Social media" or "Colleges should teach digital literacy"?
Answer: The latter
Rationale: It makes a claim.

Question 2: Align a topic sentence with a thesis about later class times.
Answer: "Later starts reduce first‑year absences."
Rationale: Advances a reason.

Question 3: Fix "This paper will explore sleep."
Answer: "Later start times improve sleep and grades."
Rationale: Concrete, arguable.

metadata.title: Thesis & Topic Sentences
metadata.retrieval_queries: thesis vs topic | align reasons | claim-evidence structure
metadata.citations: Purdue OWL: Thesis Statements - Purdue OWL
metadata.text:
Question 1: Which is a thesis: "Social media" or "Colleges should teach digital literacy"?
Answer: The latter
Rationale: It makes a claim.

Question 2: Align a topic sentence with a thesis about later class times.
Answer: "Later starts reduce first‑year absences."
Rationale: Advances a reason.

Question 3: Fix "This paper will explore sleep."
Answer: "Later start times improve sleep and grades."
Rationale: Concrete, arguable.

text:
Worked Example for Thesis & Topic Sentences:
Step: Pick a stance and specify scope. - Why: Make it arguable.
Step: Draft two reasons as topic sentences. - Why: Preview structure.
Step: Check wording for specificity. - Why: Avoid vagueness.

text:
Evidence Integration

Evidence needs setup and analysis: introduce the source, provide the quote/paraphrase with citation, then explain how it supports your claim. Keep quotations brief and integrate grammatically.

metadata.title: Evidence Integration
metadata.retrieval_queries: integrate evidence | signal phrases | cite and analyze
metadata.citations: Purdue OWL: Using Evidence - Purdue OWL
metadata.text:
Evidence Integration

Evidence needs setup and analysis: introduce the source, provide the quote/paraphrase with citation, then explain how it supports your claim. Keep quotations brief and integrate grammatically.

text:
Learning objectives for Evidence Integration:
Introduce, cite, and analyze evidence
Use signal phrases and context
Blend quotations/paraphrases smoothly

metadata.title: Evidence Integration
metadata.retrieval_queries: integrate evidence | signal phrases | cite and analyze
metadata.citations: Purdue OWL: Using Evidence - Purdue OWL
metadata.text:
Learning objectives for Evidence Integration:
Introduce, cite, and analyze evidence
Use signal phrases and context
Blend quotations/paraphrases smoothly

text:
Misconception 1: Quotes speak for themselves.
Refutation: They need analysis.
Explanation: Explain relevance.

Misconception 2: Paraphrases don’t need citation.
Refutation: They do.
Explanation: Ideas still come from the source.

metadata.title: Evidence Integration
metadata.retrieval_queries: integrate evidence | signal phrases | cite and analyze
metadata.citations: Purdue OWL: Using Evidence - Purdue OWL
metadata.text:
Misconception 1: Quotes speak for themselves.
Refutation: They need analysis.
Explanation: Explain relevance.

Misconception 2: Paraphrases don’t need citation.
Refutation: They do.
Explanation: Ideas still come from the source.

text:
Question 1: What follows a quotation?
Answer: Your analysis
Rationale: Tie to claim.

Question 2: Signal phrase example?
Answer: "As Smith (2023) argues,"
Rationale: Introduces source.

Question 3: When to paraphrase vs quote?
Answer: Paraphrase for ideas; quote for precise wording
Rationale: Depends on purpose.

Question 3: When to paraphrase vs quote?

text:
Worked Example for Evidence Integration:
Step: Introduce the source and context. - Why: Prepare the reader.
Step: Blend the quote into your syntax; cite. - Why: Maintain grammar and credit.
Step: Analyze how it supports your claim. - Why: Make relevance explicit.

text:
Descriptive Stats: Mean, Median, Mode

Mean is the arithmetic average, median is the middle value, and mode is the most common. For skewed data or outliers, median often better represents typical values.

metadata.title: Descriptive Stats: Mean, Median, Mode
metadata.retrieval_queries: mean median mode | robust center | skew and outliers
metadata.citations: OpenIntro: Descriptive Stats - OpenIntro
metadata.text:
Descriptive Stats: Mean, Median, Mode

Mean is the arithmetic average, median is the middle value, and mode is the most common. For skewed data or outliers, median often better represents typical values.

text:
Learning objectives for Descriptive Stats: Mean, Median, Mode:
Compute mean, median, and mode
Choose appropriate center for skew/outliers
Compare center and spread qualitatively

metadata.title: Descriptive Stats: Mean, Median, Mode
metadata.retrieval_queries: mean median mode | robust center | skew and outliers
metadata.citations: OpenIntro: Descriptive Stats - OpenIntro
metadata.text:
Learning objectives for Descriptive Stats: Mean, Median, Mode:
Compute mean, median, and mode
Choose appropriate center for skew/outliers
Compare center and spread qualitatively

text:
Misconception 1: Mean is always best center.
Refutation: Median resists outliers.
Explanation: Robustness matters.

Misconception 2: Mode exists only for discrete data.
Refutation: Continuous data can be binned; but mode is less stable.
Explanation: Interpret carefully.

metadata.title: Descriptive Stats: Mean, Median, Mode
metadata.retrieval_queries: mean median mode | robust center | skew and outliers
metadata.citations: OpenIntro: Descriptive Stats - OpenIntro
metadata.text:
Misconception 1: Mean is always best center.
Refutation: Median resists outliers.
Explanation: Robustness matters.

Misconception 2: Mode exists only for discrete data.
Refutation: Continuous data can be binned; but mode is less stable.
Explanation: Interpret carefully.

text:
Question 1: Mean of 2,2,3,9?
Answer: 4
Rationale: Sum 16/4.

Question 2: Median of 2,2,3,9?
Answer: (2+3)/2=2.5
Rationale: Even n: average middle two.

Question 3: Which center for salaries with a few very high values?
Answer: Median
Rationale: Resists outliers.

metadata.title: Descriptive Stats: Mean, Median, Mode
metadata.retrieval_queries: mean median mode | robust center | skew and outliers
metadata.citations: OpenIntro: Descriptive Stats - OpenIntro
metadata.text:
Question 1: Mean of 2,2,3,9?
Answer: 4
Rationale: Sum 16/4.

Question 2: Median of 2,2,3,9?
Answer: (2+3)/2=2.5
Rationale: Even n: average middle two.

Question 3: Which center for salaries with a few very high values?
Answer: Median
Rationale: Resists outliers.

text:
Worked Example for Descriptive Stats: Mean, Median, Mode:
Step: Mean: (1+2+2+3+10)/5=18/5=3.6. - Why: Average formula.
Step: Median: sorted → 1,2,2,3,10 → 2. - Why: Middle value.
Step: Interpret: mean>median suggests right skew. - Why: Long right tail.

Step: Median: sorted → 1,2,2,3,10 → 2. - Why: Middle value.
Step: Interpret: mean>median suggests right skew. - Why: Long right tail.

text:
Source Evaluation: Authority & Purpose

Evaluate sources using criteria such as authority (credentials), accuracy (evidence and methods), currency (date), purpose (inform, sell, persuade), and audience. Cross‑check key claims.

metadata.title: Source Evaluation: Authority & Purpose
metadata.retrieval_queries: source credibility | authority accuracy currency purpose | primary vs secondary
metadata.citations: ACRL Framework: Authority Is Constructed and Contextual - ACRL
metadata.text:
Source Evaluation: Authority & Purpose

Evaluate sources using criteria such as authority (credentials), accuracy (evidence and methods), currency (date), purpose (inform, sell, persuade), and audience. Cross‑check key claims.

text:
Learning objectives for Source Evaluation: Authority & Purpose:
Assess author credentials and evidence quality
Identify purpose, audience, and bias
Prefer primary/peer‑reviewed sources when appropriate

metadata.title: Source Evaluation: Authority & Purpose
metadata.retrieval_queries: source credibility | authority accuracy currency purpose | primary vs secondary
metadata.citations: ACRL Framework: Authority Is Constructed and Contextual - ACRL
metadata.text:
Learning objectives for Source Evaluation: Authority & Purpose:
Assess author credentials and evidence quality
Identify purpose, audience, and bias
Prefer primary/peer‑reviewed sources when appropriate

text:
Misconception 1: All .edu/.org sources are automatically credible.
Refutation: Evaluate content, not just domain.
Explanation: Quality varies.

Misconception 2: Peer review guarantees truth.
Refutation: It improves quality but errors persist.
Explanation: Read methods and limitations.

metadata.title: Source Evaluation: Authority & Purpose
metadata.retrieval_queries: source credibility | authority accuracy currency purpose | primary vs secondary
metadata.citations: ACRL Framework: Authority Is Constructed and Contextual - ACRL
metadata.text:
Misconception 1: All .edu/.org sources are automatically credible.
Refutation: Evaluate content, not just domain.
Explanation: Quality varies.

Misconception 2: Peer review guarantees truth.
Refutation: It improves quality but errors persist.
Explanation: Read methods and limitations.

text:
Question 1: What signals authority?
Answer: Relevant credentials, affiliations, citations
Rationale: Expertise and evidence.

Question 2: Purpose of a sponsored report?
Answer: Persuasion/marketing
Rationale: Check for bias.

Question 3: Primary vs secondary?
Answer: Original data vs analysis/synthesis
Rationale: Type of evidence.

metadata.title: Source Evaluation: Authority & Purpose
metadata.retrieval_queries: source credibility | authority accuracy currency purpose | primary vs secondary
metadata.citations: ACRL Framework: Authority Is Constructed and Contextual - ACRL
metadata.text:
Question 1: What signals authority?
Answer: Relevant credentials, affiliations, citations
Rationale: Expertise and evidence.

Question 2: Purpose of a sponsored report?
Answer: Persuasion/marketing
Rationale: Check for bias.

Question 3: Primary vs secondary?
Answer: Original data vs analysis/synthesis
Rationale: Type of evidence.

text:
Worked Example for Source Evaluation: Authority & Purpose:
Step: Check the survey’s methodology and sample. - Why: Assess evidence quality.
Step: Investigate author credentials and conflicts. - Why: Authority and bias.
Step: Cross‑check with peer‑reviewed studies. - Why: Corroboration.

text:
Propositions & Truth Tables

A proposition is a statement that is true or false. Connectives: ¬ (not), ∧ (and), ∨ (or inclusive), → (implies), ↔ (iff). Truth tables enumerate outcomes for all assignments to variables.

metadata.title: Propositions & Truth Tables
metadata.retrieval_queries: truth table | logical connectives | tautology contradiction contingency
metadata.citations: Discrete Math: Propositional Logic - Open resource
metadata.text:
Propositions & Truth Tables

A proposition is a statement that is true or false. Connectives: ¬ (not), ∧ (and), ∨ (or inclusive), → (implies), ↔ (iff). Truth tables enumerate outcomes for all assignments to variables.

text:
Learning objectives for Propositions & Truth Tables:
Define propositions and logical connectives
Construct small truth tables
Classify tautology, contradiction, contingency

metadata.title: Propositions & Truth Tables
metadata.retrieval_queries: truth table | logical connectives | tautology contradiction contingency
metadata.citations: Discrete Math: Propositional Logic - Open resource
metadata.text:
Learning objectives for Propositions & Truth Tables:
Define propositions and logical connectives
Construct small truth tables
Classify tautology, contradiction, contingency

text:
Misconception 1: ‘Or’ is exclusive by default.
Refutation: In logic, ∨ is inclusive unless stated.
Explanation: True if either or both.

Misconception 2: p→q is true only when p and q are both true.
Refutation: It is false only when p is true and q is false.
Explanation: Definition of implication.

metadata.title: Propositions & Truth Tables
metadata.retrieval_queries: truth table | logical connectives | tautology contradiction contingency
metadata.citations: Discrete Math: Propositional Logic - Open resource
metadata.text:
Misconception 1: ‘Or’ is exclusive by default.
Refutation: In logic, ∨ is inclusive unless stated.
Explanation: True if either or both.

Misconception 2: p→q is true only when p and q are both true.
Refutation: It is false only when p is true and q is false.
Explanation: Definition of implication.

text:
Question 1: When is p∨q false?
Answer: Only when both p and q are false
Rationale: Inclusive or.

Question 2: When is p→q false?
Answer: p true, q false
Rationale: Counterexample to implication.

Question 3: What is a tautology?
Answer: Always true
Rationale: No matter truth values.

metadata.title: Propositions & Truth Tables
metadata.retrieval_queries: truth table | logical connectives | tautology contradiction contingency
metadata.citations: Discrete Math: Propositional Logic - Open resource
metadata.text:
Question 1: When is p∨q false?
Answer: Only when both p and q are false
Rationale: Inclusive or.

Question 2: When is p→q false?
Answer: p true, q false
Rationale: Counterexample to implication.

Question 3: What is a tautology?
Answer: Always true
Rationale: No matter truth values.

text:
Worked Example for Propositions & Truth Tables:
Step: Enumerate (p,q) in {TT, TF, FT, FF}. - Why: All assignments.
Step: Compute p∧q, then implication. - Why: Order of evaluation.
Step: Result is always true → tautology. - Why: If both, then p is certainly true.
